Apple Products Analysis Anshuo Wu, Shengdi Chen 2021-11-13 Chapter 1 Introduction Apple is one of the biggest technology companies in the world today. They have launched various products such as IPhone, IPad, MacBook, and so forth. They provide so many opportunities for the customers by offering a wide range of products. They have come up with everything a person may want and desire. Apple is one of the most valued brand all over the world. The way Apple design their products and the strategies they use to advertise their products contribute to the success of the company. Our final project for EDAV class will employ some data visualization tools to analyze how Apple changes its products over generations. Specifically, we will analyze the change in screen sizes, camera pixels, and battery life, etc. Then based on these changes, we will explore Apple’s financial data to discover any relationship between the change of the products with the company’s sales and revenues. We will also discuss and analyze missing values. In the end, we will compare the characteristics of changes in Apple products with other popular smartphones to learn more about the common changes in smartphones. We aim to discover more about the vast technology market from those common changes. The questions we are interested in studying in this project: By comparing different features, like size, camera pixel, and battery life, of Apple products and how fast they were changing during these years, can we infer how customers’ needs had been changed? How did Apple’s financial data change over the years, and how did the change inform us of the financial circumstances of Apple? How did the sales and revenue change and what could cause those changes? Are the changes of Apple products specific to Apple itself? Can we see similar changes in other popular smartphones? What can we learn about the technology market from the general changes in all smartphones? Are customers satisfied with those changes? How did they affect customer satisfaction?

Chapter 2 Data sources Anshuo and Shengdi are both responsible for collecting the data. Our data mainly from Wikipedia. There are many useful and official dataset in Wikipedia. List of iOS and iPadOS devices: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_iOS_and_iPadOS_devices Explanation: This dataset contains a list of Apple’s devices and compares different features of those products. For instance, it compares power, storage, charging rate, and cameras for each Apple device. It can help us to visualize the difference of features among each generation of devices. By looking at the changes among those devices, we can estimate how fast they change in the past years. Comparison of Macintosh Models: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Macintosh_models Explanation: This dataset mainly compares Apple’s Macbooks in different generations. It compares features like storage, memory, and processors in a similar manner as the last dataset. By looking at the changes, we can visualize the rate of change among different generations. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPhone Explanation: This dataset examines different generations of iPhones in more detail. It particularly includes the launch price for each generation of iPhone. This feature helps examine the relationship between the change of the products with the company’s sales and revenues. Finance Table: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. Explanation: The above Wikipedia page includes the financial data of Apple from 2000 to 2020. It contains the company’s revenue, net income, total assets, and number of employees across the years. This information helps us to understand Apple’s change of financial circumstances within the last ten years. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_Apple_Inc._products Explanation: This dataset includes the timeline of the release of each apple product. It shows the products that Apple continues to innovate and the products that Apple has tried to manufacture. This information helps us examine the motivations behind the change of each Apple product. Comparison of Smartphones: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_smartphones Explanation: This dataset compares different brands of smartphones, including iPhones. It helps us to see the changes in other smartphones, and then relate them to the changes we discover in iPhones. This relationship helps us to answer whether the change of Apple products is unique to itself. If the change can be seen in all smartphones, then we will discover more about the general technology market. Customer Satisfaction Index: https://www.macrumors.com/2020/05/19/apple-smartphone-customer-satisfaction-index/ https://www.theacsi.org/acsi-benchmarks/benchmarks-by-brand/benchmarks-for-smartphones Explanation: This dataset shows how customers are satisfied with iPhones and smartphones of other brands. We will analyze how customers reacted to the products’ changes over the years.

Chapter 4 Missing values For this section, we did the missing value analysis on the finance table we found on wikipedia. library(rvest) library(robotstxt) library(tidyverse) library(patchwork) library(naniar) plot_missing <- function(dataset, percent = FALSE) { # Creating tables for plots missing_patterns <- data.frame(is.na(dataset)) %>% group_by_all() %>% count(name = "count", sort = TRUE) %>% ungroup() tidydata <- missing_patterns[,1:(ncol(missing_patterns)-1)] %>% rownames_to_column("id") %>% gather(key,value,-id) row_count <- missing_patterns %>% rownames_to_column("id") %>% mutate(row_percent=(count/sum(count)*100)) num_rows_miss <- data.frame(colSums(is.na(dataset))) colnames(num_rows_miss) <- c("count") num_rows_miss <- num_rows_miss %>% mutate(row_percent=(count/nrow(dataset)*100)) %>% arrange(desc(count)) # Find the row index of the complete cases complete_row <- as.character(which(apply(row_count[,2:(ncol(row_count)-2)], 1, function(r) all(r == FALSE)))) # Specify the correct order of the variables according to row_count table order_of_variables <- levels(fct_reorder(rownames(num_rows_miss),-num_rows_miss$count)) tidydata$key <- tidydata$key %>% factor(levels = order_of_variables) tidydata$alp <- as.factor(ifelse(tidydata$id == complete_row, 1, 0.7)) # Plot the missing pattern plots ---- Main Plot #mid_name <- rownames(num_rows_miss)[nrow(num_rows_miss)%/%2+1] mid_name<-order_of_variables[length(order_of_variables)/2] p_main <- ggplot(tidydata,aes(x=key,y=fct_rev(fct_inorder(id)),fill=value, alpha=factor(alp))) + geom_tile(color="white") + scale_fill_manual(values = c("grey", "mediumpurple")) + scale_alpha_manual(values= c("1"=1,"0.7"=0.7),guide="none") + theme_bw() + theme(legend.position = "none", panel.grid.major = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor = element_blank()) + labs(x="Variable",y="Missing Pattern") + annotate(geom="text",x=mid_name,y=complete_row,label="complete cases") # Plot the counts/percentage for missing by patterns ---- Right-hand side Plot row_count$alp <- as.factor(ifelse(row_count$id == complete_row, 1, 0.5)) if (percent) { p_right <- ggplot(row_count,aes(x=fct_rev(fct_inorder(id)),y=row_percent,alpha=factor(alp))) + geom_bar(stat = "identity",fill="royalblue") + coord_flip() + ylim(0, 100) + labs(y="% Row") } else { p_right <- ggplot(row_count,aes(x=fct_rev(fct_inorder(id)),y=count,alpha=factor(alp))) + geom_bar(stat = "identity",fill="royalblue") + coord_flip() + labs(y="Row Count") } p_right <- p_right + theme_bw() + theme(axis.title.y=element_blank(), panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank()) + scale_alpha_manual(values= c("1"=1,"0.5"=0.5), guide="none") # Plot the counts/percentage for missing by column ---- topside Plot if (percent) { p_top <- ggplot(num_rows_miss,aes(y=row_percent,x=fct_reorder(rownames(num_rows_miss),-row_percent))) + geom_bar(stat = "identity",fill="royalblue",alpha=0.5) + ylim(0, 100) + labs(y=expression(paste("% rows \n missing:"))) } else { p_top <- ggplot(num_rows_miss,aes(y=count,x=fct_reorder(rownames(num_rows_miss),-count))) + geom_bar(stat = "identity",fill="royalblue",alpha=0.5) + labs(y=expression(paste("num rows \n missing:"))) } p_top <- p_top + theme_bw() + theme(axis.title.x=element_blank(), panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(), panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank()) + ggtitle("Missing Value Patterns") # Use patchwork to put 3 plots together p_final <- p_top + plot_spacer() + p_main + p_right + plot_layout(widths = c(2, 0.5),heights = c(0.5,2)) return(p_final) } if (paths_allowed("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc.")) { webdata <- read_html("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc.") table <- webdata %>% html_table() financeTable <- table[[4]] %>% replace_with_na_if(.predicate = is.character, condition = ~.x %in% ("N/A")) colnames(financeTable) <- abbreviate(names(financeTable), minlength=2) plot_missing(financeTable, FALSE) } plot_missing(financeTable, TRUE) We want to discover the reason behind the missing values, so we first print out the missing patterns of the finance table. summary(financeTable) ## Yr RmU NimU TamU Em ## Length:21 Length:21 Length:21 Length:21 Length:21 ## Class :character Class :character Class :character Class :character Class :character ## Mode :character Mode :character Mode :character Mode :character Mode :character missing_fin <- data.frame(is.na(financeTable)) missing_fin ## Yr RmU NimU TamU Em ## 1 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE ## 2 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE ## 3 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE ## 4 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE ## 5 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE ## 6 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 7 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 8 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 9 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 10 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 11 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 12 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 13 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 14 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 15 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 16 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 17 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 18 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 19 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 20 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ## 21 FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE As we can see from the missing pattern table, the missing values of employees occur in the first five rows.
